unit_title: Equilibrium: Balanced Forces and Zero Acceleration
subject: Physics
expanded_description: Master the concept of equilibrium where balanced forces result in zero acceleration. Explore different types of equilibrium including vertical, horizontal, and rotational scenarios. Understand how objects remain stationary or move with constant velocity when net force equals zero.

core_concept.principle: Equilibrium: State where net force equals zero, resulting in zero acceleration ($\Sigma F = 0$)
core_concept.explanation: In equilibrium, all forces balance perfectly. Objects either remain at rest (static equilibrium) or move with constant velocity (dynamic equilibrium). The vector sum of all forces in every direction equals zero.

image.alt: Free-body diagram showing balanced forces in equilibrium
image.caption: Equilibrium condition: All force vectors sum to zero, resulting in no acceleration

sections.introduction: Equilibrium represents the state of perfect balance where forces cancel each other out. This fundamental concept explains why objects remain stationary or maintain constant motion without acceleration.

key_concept.definition: Equilibrium: Condition where net external force equals zero ($\Sigma \vec{F} = 0$), causing zero acceleration
key_concept.context: Equilibrium occurs when forces balance in all directions, allowing objects to maintain their current motion state indefinitely.

principles.statement: Vector sum of all forces acting on object equals zero: $\Sigma F_x = 0$ and $\Sigma F_y = 0$
principles.application: For equilibrium analysis, resolve forces into components and ensure sum equals zero in each direction
principles.example: Book on table: Weight down = Normal force up, so $\Sigma F_y = 0$. No horizontal forces, so $\Sigma F_x = 0$

principles.statement: When $\Sigma \vec{F} = 0$, acceleration $\vec{a} = 0$ according to Newton's Second Law
principles.application: Objects in equilibrium maintain constant velocity (including zero velocity)
principles.example: Car cruising at constant speed: Engine force forward = friction/air resistance backward, so $\Sigma F_x = 0$ and velocity constant

principles.statement: Static: Object at rest ($v = 0$). Dynamic: Object moving with constant velocity ($v = \text{constant}$)
principles.application: Both states satisfy $\Sigma \vec{F} = 0$ - difference is in initial conditions, not force balance
principles.example: Parked car (static) vs car on cruise control (dynamic) - both have zero net force

examples.explanation: $\Sigma F_x = 0$ and $\Sigma F_y = 0$ must both be satisfied simultaneously
Forces must cancel as vectors - both magnitude and direction matter
Break forces into x and y components, sum components separately, both sums must equal zero

sections.introduction: When forces balance perfectly in all directions, objects remain completely stationary. This static equilibrium explains the stability of structures, furniture, and countless everyday objects.

key_concept.definition: Static Equilibrium: Object at rest with all forces balanced ($\Sigma \vec{F} = 0$ and $v = 0$)
key_concept.context: Static equilibrium requires both force balance and initial stationary condition - the object remains motionless indefinitely.

image.alt: Various objects in static equilibrium with force diagrams
image.caption: Static equilibrium: Balanced forces maintain stationary state - objects at rest stay at rest

classifications.value: Everyday objects remaining stationary due to force balance
classifications.behavior: Objects remain at rest as long as force balance maintains and no disturbance occurs

examples.explanation: Weight ($mg$ down) balanced by normal force ($N$ up). No horizontal forces. $\Sigma F_x = 0$, $\Sigma F_y = 0$
Weight down balanced by tension up in supporting cable or chain
Weight balanced by foundation support forces, lateral forces balanced by structural elements
Weight of bridge and traffic balanced by upward forces from piers and cables

classifications.value: Systematic approach to verify static equilibrium
classifications.behavior: Methodical process to ensure all forces cancel in every direction

examples.explanation: Identify all forces acting on object with correct directions and points of application
Establish x and y axes, typically horizontal and vertical for simplicity
Break each force into x and y components: $F_x = F\cos\theta$, $F_y = F\sin\theta$
Calculate $\Sigma F_x$ and $\Sigma F_y$, both must equal zero for equilibrium

process_flow.description: Object stationary with no motion observed
List every force acting on the object
process_flow.mechanism: Consider weight, normal forces, tension, friction, applied forces, etc.
Sum force components in each coordinate direction
Observe no acceleration or velocity change

sections.introduction: Vertical equilibrium occurs when upward and downward forces balance perfectly. This is crucial for understanding why objects don't accelerate vertically and how structures support weight.

key_concept.definition: Vertical Equilibrium: Sum of vertical forces equals zero ($\Sigma F_y = 0$), preventing vertical acceleration
key_concept.context: In vertical equilibrium, upward forces exactly balance downward forces, resulting in no vertical motion or constant vertical velocity.

categories.detailed_mechanism: Upward support forces (normal, tension, buoyancy) equal downward weight force

examples.explanation: Weight $mg$ down balanced by normal force $N$ up: $N = mg$, so $\Sigma F_y = N - mg = 0$
Weight down balanced by tension up: $T = mg$, so $\Sigma F_y = T - mg = 0$
Weight down balanced by buoyant force up: $F_b = mg$, so $\Sigma F_y = F_b - mg = 0$
Weight down balanced by normal force from floor up through feet

categories.description: Solving for unknown forces in vertical equilibrium
categories.detailed_mechanism: Use $\Sigma F_y = 0$ to determine unknown vertical forces when mass or weight is known

examples.explanation: For object on level surface: $N = mg$. On scale: reading shows $N = mg$
For single vertical cable: $T = mg$. For multiple cables: sum of vertical components = $mg$
For floating object: $F_b = mg = \rho_{fluid} V_{displaced} g$
At constant velocity: scale reading = $mg$. Accelerating: scale reading $\neq mg$ (not equilibrium)

principles.statement: Gravity provides constant downward force $mg$ on all objects with mass
principles.application: Vertical equilibrium requires upward force(s) summing to $mg$ to balance weight
principles.example: Book on table: normal force up = weight down. Hanging lamp: tension up = weight down

principles.statement: When multiple supports share load, sum of their vertical forces equals total weight
principles.application: $\Sigma F_y = F_1 + F_2 + F_3 + ... - mg = 0$ for multiple supports
principles.example: Table with four legs: sum of normal forces from all four legs equals table + object weight

principles.statement: Any vertical acceleration indicates $\Sigma F_y \neq 0$ - not in vertical equilibrium
principles.application: Scale readings different from $mg$ indicate vertical acceleration
principles.example: Elevator starting upward: scale reading > $mg$ ($\Sigma F_y > 0$, upward acceleration)

sections.introduction: Horizontal equilibrium ensures no side-to-side acceleration. This occurs when left-right forces balance perfectly, explaining why objects remain centered or move with constant horizontal velocity.

key_concept.definition: Horizontal Equilibrium: Sum of horizontal forces equals zero ($\Sigma F_x = 0$), preventing horizontal acceleration
key_concept.context: In horizontal equilibrium, leftward and rightward forces cancel, resulting in no horizontal motion or constant horizontal velocity.

image.alt: Objects in horizontal equilibrium with balanced left-right forces
image.caption: Horizontal equilibrium: Leftward and rightward forces balance, preventing side-to-side acceleration

process_flow.description: List all forces with horizontal components
process_flow.mechanism: Consider applied pushes/pulls, friction, tension components, normal forces on inclines

process_flow.description: Establish positive and negative horizontal directions
process_flow.mechanism: Typically right = positive x, left = negative x
Add forces in positive direction, subtract forces in negative direction
Check that positive and negative contributions cancel exactly

classifications.behavior: Objects either stationary horizontally or moving with constant horizontal speed

examples.explanation: No horizontal forces act, so $\Sigma F_x = 0$ automatically - object maintains horizontal velocity
Applied push force balanced by friction force: $F_{push} = f_{friction}$, so $\Sigma F_x = 0$
Both teams pull equally: left tension = right tension, so $\Sigma F_x = 0$ - rope stationary
Engine force forward = air resistance + rolling friction backward, so $\Sigma F_x = 0$

classifications.behavior: Use $\Sigma F_x = 0$ to find unknown horizontal forces or verify equilibrium

examples.explanation: For object moving at constant speed: $f_{friction} = F_{applied}$ since $\Sigma F_x = 0$
Object at rest on incline: $f_{friction} = mg\sin\theta$ (component of weight parallel to surface)
Sum of all leftward forces = sum of all rightward forces for $\Sigma F_x = 0$
Horizontal components of tension must cancel for horizontal equilibrium

sections.introduction: Rotational equilibrium occurs when torques balance perfectly, preventing rotation or maintaining constant rotational speed. This ensures objects don't start spinning or change their rotation rate.

key_concept.definition: Rotational Equilibrium: Sum of torques equals zero ($\Sigma \tau = 0$), preventing angular acceleration
key_concept.context: Rotational equilibrium requires both force balance ($\Sigma F = 0$) and torque balance ($\Sigma \tau = 0$) for complete equilibrium.

principles.statement: Torque ($\tau$) = force × lever arm: $\tau = F \times r \times \sin\theta$, where $r$ is distance from pivot
principles.application: Torque depends on force magnitude, direction, and point of application relative to pivot
principles.example: Pushing perpendicular on door far from hinges creates large torque. Pushing toward hinges creates zero torque.

principles.statement: For rotational equilibrium: $\Sigma \tau = 0$ (sum of clockwise torques = sum of counterclockwise torques)
principles.application: Calculate torques about any pivot point; sum must equal zero for no rotation
principles.example: See-saw balanced: weight × distance on left = weight × distance on right

principles.statement: Complete equilibrium requires both $\Sigma F = 0$ and $\Sigma \tau = 0$
principles.application: Must check both force balance and torque balance to ensure object won't translate or rotate
principles.example: Ladder against wall: vertical and horizontal forces balance, and torques about base balance

categories.description: Objects that don't rotate due to balanced torques

examples.explanation: $m_1 g r_1 = m_2 g r_2$ so $\Sigma \tau = 0$ about pivot - see-saw remains level
Torque from weight balanced by torque from wall support - sign doesn't rotate
Torque from weight about base balanced by torque from normal force from wall
Driving torque balanced by friction torque - wheel rotates at constant speed
Select convenient point (often where unknown forces act) to eliminate those forces from torque equation
Find perpendicular distance from pivot to line of force action
Clockwise torques negative, counterclockwise positive (or vice versa)
Set sum of torques equal to zero and solve for unknown quantities

sections.introduction: Complete equilibrium requires satisfying all equilibrium conditions simultaneously. This comprehensive analysis ensures objects remain completely stationary or move with constant velocity without rotating.

key_concept.definition: Complete Equilibrium: All equilibrium conditions satisfied: $\Sigma F_x = 0$, $\Sigma F_y = 0$, and $\Sigma \tau = 0$
key_concept.context: Complete equilibrium guarantees no translation and no rotation - the object maintains its exact motion state indefinitely.

image.alt: Complete equilibrium analysis showing force and torque balance
image.caption: Complete equilibrium: All forces balance ($\Sigma F = 0$) and all torques balance ($\Sigma \tau = 0$)

classifications.value: Different scenarios requiring complete equilibrium analysis
classifications.behavior: All require force balance in all directions and torque balance about any point

examples.explanation: Sum of vertical forces = weight, and torques about any point balance
Vertical components of tensions sum to weight, horizontal components cancel, torques balance
Vertical forces balance, horizontal forces balance, torques about base balance
Complex force and torque balance involving boom, cable, counterweight, and support

classifications.value: Systematic approach to complete equilibrium problems
classifications.behavior: Methodical process ensuring all equilibrium conditions are satisfied

examples.explanation: Show all forces with correct directions and points of application
$\Sigma F_x = 0$ and $\Sigma F_y = 0$
$\Sigma \tau = 0$ about convenient pivot point
Use the three equations to find up to three unknowns

process_flow.description: Clearly define the object or system to analyze
process_flow.mechanism: Determine boundaries and what forces act on the system

process_flow.description: Show all external forces acting on system
process_flow.mechanism: Include weight, normal forces, tension, friction, applied forces with correct directions

process_flow.description: Write and solve the three equilibrium equations
Solve for unknowns and verify solution makes physical sense
process_flow.mechanism: Check directions, magnitudes, and that all conditions are satisfied

summary: Equilibrium occurs when all forces balance perfectly, resulting in zero acceleration. Static equilibrium describes stationary objects ($\Sigma F = 0$ and $v = 0$), while dynamic equilibrium describes objects moving with constant velocity ($\Sigma F = 0$ and $v = \text{constant}$). Vertical equilibrium requires upward and downward forces to cancel ($\Sigma F_y = 0$), horizontal equilibrium requires leftward and rightward forces to balance ($\Sigma F_x = 0$), and rotational equilibrium requires torques to cancel ($\Sigma \tau = 0$). Complete equilibrium satisfies all three conditions simultaneously, ensuring no translation and no rotation. Understanding equilibrium is essential for analyzing structures, mechanical systems, and everyday situations where forces balance to maintain motion states.
